results.summary_short: “Johnny Mad Dog” is a film based on a novel by the Congolese writer Emmanuel Dongala.

results.summary_short: Kiran Rao’s moody film is set in Bombay.

results.headline: A Firm Commitment to Casual

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Strings Attached

results.summary_short: Natalie Portman and Ashton Kutcher star in a brisk romantic comedy distinguished by a dose of semi-cynical sexual candor.

results.headline: Taking Up With a Maid Might Upset the Family

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Housemaid

results.summary_short: In “The Housemaid,” Im Sang-soo has made a film that swings from psychological thriller to comedy of manners to erotic romp to feminist fable.

results.headline: Even on the Wagon, Not Ready for a Close-Up

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Applause

results.summary_short: Paprika Steen stars as an alcoholic actress in “Applause,” by Martin Pieter Zandvliet.

results.headline: Addicted and Adrift in Post-Soviet World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Street Days

results.summary_short: A debut feature by Levan Koguashvili shows men adrift in post-Soviet Georgia.

results.headline: Self-Portrait of the Artist as a Suicide

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Woodmans

results.summary_short: This documentary focuses on the artistic family of a young photographer who committed suicide.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zenith

results.summary_short: Vladan Nikolic’s “Zenith” is an atmospheric thriller that the audience can join through the Web.

results.summary_short: “Ong Bak 3” begins with a recap of its predecessor, and that may be the best part of this martial-arts movie.

results.headline: If It’s Not One Thing, It’s Another

results.summary_short: “Every Day” is a fairly accurate portrait of the pressures of modern-day middle-class life.

results.headline: In States of Undress, Mental and Physical

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Twelve Thirty

results.summary_short: The indie filmmaker Jeff Lipsky examines an eccentric Iowa City family in “Twelve Thirty.”

results.headline: Humanity Under Layers of Grit and After Years of Crime

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Somewhat Gentle Man

results.summary_short: A humane sensibility is revealed by Stellan Skarsgard as Ulrik, a reformed killer in “A Somewhat Gentle Man,” a Norwegian entry into the deadpan gangster comedy genre.

results.headline: Latest Celebutante Satire Already Out of Date

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Repo Chick

results.summary_short: Alex Cox’s “Repo” franchise goes off the rails with Jaclyn Jonet’s spectacularly shallow performance in “Repo Chick.”

results.headline: Celluloid Critique of Plastic’s Perils

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Plastic Planet

results.summary_short: Plastic, one of the most ubiquitous materials on earth, is the target of “Plastic Planet,” an environmental warning by the Austrian filmmaker Werner Boothe.

results.headline: In China, You Can’t Fight City Hall

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Petition

results.summary_short: In a new film made up of true stories collected over a decade, Chinese citizens who try to fight city hall find themselves battling entrenched and unscrupulous forces.

results.headline: Have Cool Car and Mask (and Sidekick), Will Travel for Justice

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Green Hornet

results.summary_short: “The Green Hornet,” a film based on an ancient and much-adapted radio serial, lands Seth Rogen in the title role and Michel Gondry behind the camera.

results.headline: A Guy Thing? Not That Kind. And Not That Kind Either.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dilemma

results.summary_short: In “The Dilemma,” the two main characters love each other dearly, but their love is tested by difficult circumstances.

results.headline: Breaking Records Won’t Win Celebrity for Peculiar Elite

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breaking and Entering

results.summary_short: Posterity, not fame or fortune, motivates the world-record seekers in the documentary “Breaking and Entering.”

results.headline: Death of an Art House Means a Start to a Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Useful Life

results.summary_short: In Federico Veiroj’s film “A Useful Life” the programmer of a failing art house faces a challenge to his hermetic existence.
